Description: Neck sherd (mended from three fragments) of Fikellura pottery closed vessel, oinochoe or amphora; pale slip; glaze fired orange; exterior: neck glazed as far as preserved, down to ridge at base; on neck, guilloche between pairs of bands; at left part of glazed handle area; above, part of tongue frieze or the like.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Modern inscription written in ink 'NAU 43' on break (accession number used in clay analysis). According to Dupont and Thomas (2006, p. 80, NAU 43), the geophysical characteristics of the fabric indicate that the sherd originated in Miletus. For parallels, see Cook, J. M. 'Fikellura Pottery', The Annual of the British School at Athens 34, 1933-1934, pl. 5.
Bibliographic references: Dupont & Thomas 2006 / Naukratis: Les Importations Grecques Orientales Archaïques (78-80, 82, 8, fig. 3) (NAU 43)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GF.156)
